option_header: Choose the phrase that you think best describes your current level of understanding:
option_one: I have difficulties identifying if an issue is ethical in nature, and I find it difficult to begin sorting the issue out.
option_two: I can usually provide an answer to a direct factual question. I can usually think of one-two things to say.
option_three: I can provide an answer to direct factual questions and I can usually say three or more items related to the topic.
option_four: I can think of several aspects about an ethical issue and I can justify my explanations and provide examples to illustrate my understanding.
option_five: I understand various aspects of ethical issues, I see connections between them and can apply my knowledge in different situations within my own research process as well as help others with their ethical questions.
form_welcome: Welcome to using the Reflection Compass!
form_free_answer: Please describe what you have been learning on the topic about the abovementioned activity/topic. You can provide examples.
answer_evaluation_form_header_0: To get on track with research ethics and integrity, you need to do some work.
answer_evaluation_form_header_1: You are on the way: You know something!
answer_evaluation_form_header_2: You are pretty knowledgeable about ethics and integrity!
answer_evaluation_form_header_3: You know ethics very well, and there is always a little room for improving further!
answer_evaluation_form_header_4: You have good competencies in research ethics and integrity!
answer_evaluation_form_text_0: Try to make sense why the topics discussed are relevant. Imagine situations in which you feel empathy or in which you feel you are guided by your values. Why are the values important to you? What would a situation, in which opposite or very different values prevail, be like? What would you do? Considering such questions will help you to think about research ethics and integrity. You can improve your ethical competence by consulting relevant codes of conduct, and to discuss with experienced researchers how they think about making right choices in research; How do they justify their points of view? Why do you think these questions are important for the research community? What is your role in it?
answer_evaluation_form_text_1: You can still deepen your competencies in research ethics and integrity by consulting relevant codes of conduct and discussing with experienced researchers. Try to grasp more aspects of ethical topics: What else is important or even necessary to make the right choices in research? Who all may be concerned about the situation, and would different people have different views on a situation? What other issues may follow from the current one? Ethical issues in research are often such that there can be related questions, or new questions may follow from the initial issue. Try to map out who all are concerned by a situation, and what kind of different questions they would raise about the situation!
answer_evaluation_form_text_2: You identify more than one dimension of ethics or integrity in an issue. Next, try to see connections between different ethical aspects in research, and think of examples to describe those connections. Who are concerned about the situation? Do different interests and points of view lead to different solutions? How does an individual’s action influence a group or a community of researchers or even an institution or field? And the other way around: If a group allows for bad research practices to flourish, how does that impact individual researchers and the colleagues they collaborate with? To learn more, you can go over relevant codes of conduct to review principles of good research practice and think about how you can implement good research practice in your own research. What can you do to ensure that your research is up to the highest ethical and integrity standards? Share ideas with others in your group or research community!
answer_evaluation_form_text_3: You are probably familiar with ethical guidelines and codes of conduct, but you may wish to update your knowledge regularly. Try to extend your knowledge beyond your own research. Find ways to apply your knowledge in various contexts and provide help to others. It is also useful to raise questions in your research group or with colleagues in order to identify how the research ethics of others influence people beyond their group, or what kind of practices support ethical research.
answer_evaluation_form_text_4: You can manage your own research and ethics, and help others manage theirs. You may have thought quite a lot about research ethics and integrity, perhaps because of your research topic and interests. You can probably recognize ethical issues in research and work on those before they turn into problems. You may have thought about yourself as a role model in promoting good scientific practice in the research community more broadly, and in helping to create an ethically sustainable research culture. Everyone can promote high standards of research ethics and integrity through their own example.

item_1_heading: The controller, i.e. the entity responsible for processing your data, is the University of Helsinki
item_1_line_6: The contact person for the controller is Erika Löfström and her contact information is as follows:
item_2_heading: The data protection officer of the University of Helsinki
item_2_line_1: You can get in touch with the data protection officer of the University of Helsinki by sending an e-mail to:
item_3_heading: 1. Why is your personal data processed, i.e. what is the purpose of the processing?
item_3_line_1: The University of Helsinki needs to process your personal data for the following purposes: The Reflection Compass is a teaching support application that is used to support students' learning and to develop teaching. Personal data are used to identify students and teachers in the system.
item_3_line_2: The Reflection Compass is a teaching support application that is used to support students' learning and to develop teaching. Personal data are used to identify students and teachers in the system. Personal data can be used for scientific research. The research information sheet is available in the system and consent to participation in research is asked separately when using the system.
item_3_line_3: Legal basis for processing personal data:
item_3_line_4: Public interest task/exercise of public authority belonging to the data controller:
item_3_line_5: scientific or historical research or statistics
item_3_line_6: the exercise of legitimate interests of the controller or a third party
item_4_heading: 2. What kind of personal data does the University of Helsinki process?
item_4_line_1: The University of Helsinki processes the following personal data:
item_4_line_6: Data can be collected from users of the program:
item_5_heading: 3. Where does the personal data come from, i.e. what is the origin of the data?
item_5_line_1: When logging in, the user name, e-mail, first name, last name, and user role are imported into the system from the target organization's centralized user management system. Username, e-mail and user role are saved in the system.
item_6_heading: 4. How long are personal data kept?
item_6_line_1: After the end of the study unit, personal data is deleted from the system within a reasonable period of time.
item_7_heading: 5. What rights do you have and deviation from rights
item_7_line_1: The contact address in matters related to the rights of the data subject is the contact information mentioned in section 1 of this notice.
item_7_line_3: You have the right to withdraw your consent if the processing of personal data is based on consent. Withdrawal of consent does not affect the legality of processing carried out on the basis of consent prior to its withdrawal.
item_7_line_5: You have the right to receive information about whether your personal data is being processed and what personal data is being processed. If you wish, you can also request a copy of the personal data being processed. All information stored in the system is visible to you after logging in.
item_7_line_7: If there are inaccuracies or errors in your personal data being processed, you have the right to request their correction or completion.
item_7_line_9: You have the right to demand the deletion of your personal data in the following cases:
item_7_line_10: personal data are no longer needed for the purposes for which they were collected or for which they were otherwise processed
item_7_line_11: you withdraw the consent on which the processing was based, and there is no other legal basis for the processing
item_7_line_12: you object to the processing (a description of the right to object is below) and there is no justified reason for the processing
item_7_line_13: personal data has been processed illegally; or
item_7_line_14: personal data must be deleted in order to comply with a statutory obligation applicable to the data controller based on Union law or Member State legislation.
item_7_line_15: However, there is no right to delete data if:
item_7_line_16: the deletion of data prevents or greatly complicates the realization of the purpose of processing in scientific research, or
item_7_line_17: if the processing of personal data is necessary to comply with a statutory obligation requiring processing based on the Union law applicable to the controller or the legislation of a Member State, or
item_7_line_18: the processing takes place for the performance of a task in the public interest or for the exercise of a public authority belonging to the controller.
item_7_line_20: You have the right to restrict the processing of your personal data. This means that we retain your data but do not process it in any other way.
item_7_line_21: You have this right in the following cases:
item_7_line_22: you dispute the accuracy of the personal data, in which case processing is limited to the time during which the university can verify their accuracy
item_7_line_23: the processing is against the law and you object to the deletion of personal data and instead demand the restriction of their use
item_7_line_24: the university no longer needs the personal data in question for processing purposes, but you need them to prepare, present or defend a legal claim
item_7_line_25: you have objected to the processing of personal data (see further below) pending verification of whether the legitimate grounds of the controller supersede the grounds of the data subject
item_7_line_27: You have the right to object to the processing of your personal data if the processing is based on a public interest or a legitimate interest. In this case, the university cannot process your personal data, unless it can demonstrate that there is a significantly important and justified reason for the processing that overrides the interests, rights and freedoms of the data subject, or if it is necessary to prepare, present or defend a legal claim. The university can continue processing your personal data even when it is necessary to perform a task in the public interest.
item_7_line_29: You have the right to file a complaint with the data protection commissioner's office if you believe that valid data protection legislation has been violated in the processing of your personal data.
item_7_line_31: Office of the Data Protection Commissioner
